clinical_validity.disease_label: obsolete autosomal recessive hereditary demyelinating motor and sensory neuropathy
clinical_validity.gcep: Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease Gene Curation Expert Panel

generif.text: This paper presents an analysis of the SH3TC2 promoter after identifying a read-through transcript of the SH3TC2 and HTR4 loci. Available data suggests HTR4 is a separate locus with its own promoter, and not the product of a bi-cistronic transcript.
mutations in an uncharacterized transcript, KIAA1985, in 12 families with autosomal recessive neuropathy
a founder mutation, p.Arg1109X in the CMT4C gene, causes variable peripheral neuropathy phenotypes
the SH3TC2 p.R1109X mutation is associated with a conserved haplotype and, therefore, may be a private founder mutation for the Gypsy population

Linkage analysis confirmed that all families are linked to CMT4C locus on chromosome 5q32 (multipoint LOD score of 9.06). Haplotype analysis suggests that two SH3TC2 mutations are present in this cohort
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
Structural alterations to the SH3TC2 gene could possibly predispose to peripheral nerve inflammation.
Missense mutations in the SH3TC2 causing Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 4C affect its localization to plasma membrane.
Mistargeting of SH3TC2 away from the recycling endosome is the fundamental molecular defect that leads to Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 4C.
Clinical trial of gene-disease association and gene-environment interaction. (HuGE Navigator)
Mutations in the SH3TC2 gene are a frequent cause of HMSN I in Czech patients.
This study presented evidence that mutations c.279G --> A and c.3676-8G -->A in the SH3TC2 gene cause aberrant splicing and are therefore pathogenic and causal for CMT4C.
Data indicate that the most frequent form is SH3TC2 gene (CMT4C; 57.14%), followed by HK1 gene causative of CMT4G (CMT4G/HMSN-Russe 25%) and NDRG1 p.R148X in CMT type 4D (CMT4D/HMSN-Lom; 17.86%).
SH3TC2 is regulated by the transcription factors CREB and SOX10, define a regulatory SNP at this disease-associated locus and reveal SH3TC2 as a candidate modifier locus of CMT disease phenotypes.
The novelty of our data is the relatively high frequency of SH3TC2 and GDAP1 mutations in demyelinating and axonal forms, respectively, of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease
DNA sequence analysis in a French-Canadian family revealed a novel combination of 2 known recessive mutations, p.R904X and p.R954X, in the SH3TC2 gene.
A homozygous missense mutation c.1894G>A of SH3TC2 is associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 4C.
In this series of undiagnosed CMT4 patients, SH3TC2 mutation frequency is 30%, confirming that CMT4C may be the most common AR-CMT type.

Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 4C (CMT4C) is an autosomal recessive demyelinating form of CMT characterized clinically by early onset and severe spinal deformities, and is caused by mutations in SH3TC2.
This present clinical and physiologic features of 5 patients with CMT4C caused by biallelic private mutations of SH3TC2.
SH3TC2, PMP2, and BSCL2 pathogenic variants might be rare in Chinese Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) patients.
Mutations in SH3TC2 are responsible for 26% of Greek patients with suspected CMT4C.
Compound heterozygous mutations of SH3TC2 in Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 4C patients.
Implication of the SH3TC2 gene in Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease associated with deafness and/or scoliosis: Illustration with four new pathogenic variants.
Screening for SH3TC2 variants in Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease in a cohort of Chinese patients.
Evaluation of Pathogenicity and Causativity of Variants in the MPZ and SH3TC2 Genes in a Family Case of Hereditary Peripheral Neuropathy.
Characterisation of Patients with SH3TC2 Associated Neuropathy in an Indian Cohort.

interpro.desc: SH3 domain and tetratricopeptide repeat-containing protein SH3TC1/SH3TC2

name: SH3 domain and tetratricopeptide repeats 2
other_names: SH3 domain and tetratricopeptide repeat-containing protein 2
SH3 domain and tetratricopeptide repeats-containing protein 2

wikipathways.name: Intracellular trafficking proteins involved in CMT neuropathy

summary: This gene encodes a protein with two N-terminal Src homology 3 (SH3) domains and 10 tetratricopeptide repeat (TPR) motifs, and is a member of a small gene family. The gene product has been proposed to be an adapter or docking molecule. Mutations in this gene result in autosomal recessive Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 4C, a childhood-onset neurodegenerative disease characterized by demyelination of motor and sensory neurons. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
